author: Sean Morrison
title: Ken Livingstone in another Nazi rant as he calls disciplinary hearing 'unfair'
text:
Mother and son stabbed to death at home as father suffers knife wounds 
Ken Livingstone caused fresh controversy as he arrived for a two-day private disciplinary hearing with the Labour Party over his comments on Hitler and Zionism. 
Almost one year after he told the BBC that Hitler was a Zionist in the early 1930s and helped German Jews emigrate to Palestine, he on Thursday said that Nazi policy at the time went further than that. 
The former London mayor repeated his claim that there was “collaboration” between the Nazi leader and the Zionist movement before World War Two, denouncing the hearing as “unfair.” 
Mr Livingstone insisted he had nothing to apologise for, repeating his previous argument that he had only stated historical fact. Ken Livingston is facing a disciplinary hearing following his comments on Hitler(Lauren Hurley/PA) 
Arriving at the disciplinary hearing on Thursday, he said: “The SS set up training camps so that German Jews who going to go there could be trained to cope with a very different sort of country when they got there.” 
“When the Zionist movement asked the Nazi Government, would they stop the Rabbis doing their sermons in Yiddish and make them do it in Hebrew - he [Hitler] agreed to that. 
“He also passed a law that said only the Zionist flag and the Swastika were the only flags that could be flown in Germany. Read more 
“And then of course they started selling Mauser pistols to the underground Jewish army. 
“So you had, right up until the start of the Second World War, real collaboration. 
“And when, in July 1937, many senior Nazis gathered at their Foreign Office, saying we should stop sending Jews to Palestine because it could create a Jewish state, a directive comes directly from Hitler saying: ‘no continue with this policy’. 
“Everyone who studies history just knows this.” 
The Labour veteran was suspended in April last year after claiming that Hitler supported Zionism in the 1930s before he "went mad and ended up killing six million Jews". 
Around one third of voters believe he should be expelled from the party, according to polling, and the Holocaust Educational Trust said Mr Livingstone had persisted in causing offence. 
A hearing run by Labour's national constitutional committee that could last up to two days will decide if he should be kicked out. 
Mr Livingstone criticised the decision to hold the process in private. 
He said: "They have dropped all the charges that I'm anti-Semitic,” adding: “They've dropped the charge that I said Hitler was a Zionist." 
He said he had "no intention" to cause offence during the BBC interview on Venessa Feltz Show, was "sorry" if his remarks did so. 
He faces a charge of engaging in conduct that was grossly detrimental to the party. 
This is not the first time Mr Livingstone has become embroiled in an anti-Semitism row. 
In 2006 a High Court judge said he made "unnecessarily offensive" and "indefensible" remarks likening a Jewish reporter to a Nazi concentration camp guard. 
But he was cleared of bringing the office of mayor into disrepute. 
The hearing has been adjourned until Friday.
